Concerning the necessity of smoothness hypotheses where the boundary is not locally convex,  we note that by Theorem 3 there exists data having arbitrary small absolute value for which no solution of the Dirichlet problem is possible.  Thus conditions involving only the magnitude of the data cannot possibly suffice for the general solvability of Dirichlet's problem.  If the boundary itself is not smooth the situation can be even worse.  By slightly " tilting " the tetrahedron example considered by Nitsche [ 13 ],  one can obtain data whose derivatives up to any order are arbitrarily small and yet for which no solution of the Dirichlet problem is possible.
